could become so dilapidated and neglected that they jeopardize or are detrimental to the health safety morals or general welfare of the people of the city or to the economic values of adjoining property c the adoption and subsequent enforcement of the ordinance codified in this chapter is therefore deemed essential to the public interest it shall be reasonably construed to maintain a pleasant safe and healthful environment and to help insure the maintenance of property values within the city prior     part 1997 definitions the following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this chapter 1 accessory structure means a garage storage building boathouse etc 2 apartment hotel means the same as hotel 3 approved means in accordance with regulation established by city ordinance or code and authority designated by law to enforce such ordinance or code 4 basement means a subordinate use which is incidental to and customary in conjunction with the principal structure or use and which is located on the same lot with such principal structure or use 5 bath means a bathtub or shower and stall properly be connected with both hot and cold waterlines 6 bathroom means a nonhabitable room within a dwelling unit which is used or intended to be used primarily for bathing andor toilet purposes and which contains a toilet lavatory bathtub or shower facilities 7 bedroom means a habitable room within a dwelling unit which is used or intended to be used primarily for the purpose of sleeping but shall not include any kitchen or dining room the term bedroom however shall not be interpreted so as to prohibit efficiency apartments 8 building inspector means a housing or health inspector public works employee or any other city employee authorized by the city council to perform inspections 9 city means the city of omro wisconsin 10 communal means used or shared by or intended to be used or shared by the occupants of two or more rooming units or two or more dwelling units 11 dwelling means a structure or portion thereof designed or used exclusively for human habitation including home trailers mobile homes and manufactured dwellings but not including hotels motels boardinghouses and lodginghouses tourist courts or tourist homes 12 dwelling multiple or apartment building multiple dwelling or apartment building means a residential structure or portion of a structure containing three or more dwelling units served by a common entrance or a structure designed for occupancy by three or more families 13 dwelling singlefamily singlefamily dwelling means a structure on a single lot containing one dwelling unit and surrounded by open space or yards and which is not attached to any other dwelling by any means 14 dwelling twofamily twofamily dwelling means a structure on a single lot containing two dwelling units each of which is totally separated from the other by an unpierced wall extending from ground to roof or an unpierced ceiling and floor extending from exterior wall to exterior wall except for a common stairwell exterior to both dwelling units 15 dwelling unit means a room or suite of rooms used as a singlefamily dwelling including bath and culinary accommodations 16 efficiency apartment means a dwelling unit consisting of one habitable room 17 extermination means the control and elimination of insects rodents or other pests by elimination of their harborage places by removing and making inaccessible material that may serve as their food by poisoning spraying trapping or by any other recognized and legal elimination methods approved by the health officer of the city 18 family means one or more persons maintaining a common household 19 garbage means the animal and vegetable waste resulting from the preparation handling cooking and consumption of food 20 habitable room means a room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living sleeping cooking or eating purposes excluding bathrooms laundries pantries foyers communicating corridors closets and storage spaces 21 hotel means a structure in which lodging or boarding and lodging are provided and offered to the public for compensation and in which ingress and egress to and from all rooms are made inside lobby or office supervised by a person in charge at all times as such it is open to the public in contradistinction to a boarding house which is herein separately defined 22 infestation means the presence of any insects rodents or other pests within a dwelling or on the dwelling premises 23 inoperable vehicle means any unregistered vehicle or any vehicle unable to move under its own power or unable to be used legally on any public street 24 kitchen means a habitable room or an area used or intended to be used for cooking or the preparation of meals 25 nuisance is defined as follows 1 any attractive nuisance which may prove detrimental to children whether in a building or upon a lot this includes any abandoned wells shafts basements and excavations  or any abandoned refrigerators and inoperable motor vehicles  or any structurally unsound structure  or any lumber and other construction material trash debris or vegetation which may prove a hazard for inquisitive minors  2 whatever is dangerous to human life or is detrimental to health  3 overcrowding a room with occupants  4 insufficient ventilation or illumination  5 inadequate or unsanitary sewerage or plumbing facilities  6 uncleanliness  7 whatever renders the air food or drink unwholesome or is detrimental to the health of human beings  8 unsafe or dangerous electrical wiring plumbing systems or heating equipment 26 occupant means any person living sleeping eating or having actual possession of a dwelling unit or rooming unit 27 operator means any person which is in charge or control of a building or part thereof in which dwelling units or rooming units are let 28 owner means any person who alone or jointly or severally with others is the legally recorded holder of the title with or without actual possession thereof or who has charge care or control of any dwelling or dwelling unit as agent or owner or as executor administrator trustee or guardian of the estate of the owner the term owner under this chapter shall also include the legally recorded holder of a land contract vendee interest 29 person means any individual firm corporation partnership or association 30 plumbing means all piping fixtures appliances equipment devices and appurtenances in connection with the water supply water distribution and drainage systems including hot water storage tanks water softeners and water heaters connected with such water and drainage systems and also includes the installation thereof or a water pressure system other than municipal systems as provided in wis stats ch 144 31 premises means a lot together with all buildings and structures thereon 32 roomer means an occupant of a roominghouse who is not a member of the family of the operator of that roominghouse or an occupant of a dwelling unit who is not a member of the family occupying the dwelling units 33 roominghouse means any dwelling or that part of any dwelling containing one or more rooming units in which space is let by the owner or operator to more than four roomers 34 rooming unit means any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable unit in a roominghouse used or intended to be used for living andor sleeping 35 rubbish means household waste except garbage  and the term shall include tin cans glass metal crockery and similar household wastes  also papers rags lawn rakings and other combustible refuse 36 supplied means paid for furnished or provided by or under the control of the owneroperator b meaning of certain words 1 whenever the words dwelling dwelling unit roominghouse or premises are used in this chapter they shall be construed as though they were followed by or any part thereof 2 all words other than those specifically defined in this chapter shall have their ordinarily accepted meanings as implied by the context prior     part 1997 inspection of premises a the building or housing inspector is authorized and directed to make inspections when heshe has valid reasons to believe that a violation of this chapter has occurred b the building or housing inspector is authorized to enter and inspect all dwellings and dwelling units subject to the provisions of this chapter between the hours of  am and  pm except for sundays and holidays for the purpose of determining whether there is compliance with the provisions of this chapter heshe shall give the occupant thereof or if there is none then the owner thereof reasonable notice of hisher intent to inspect the premises and may then make hisher inspection only if heshe is given permission to do so in the absence of such permission heshe shall obtain a special inspection warrant issued pursuant to wis stats   before entering the premises however if delay in the inspection would pose a serious and imminent threat to human life health or property heshe may enter the premises without such permission or notice and with or without such a warrant as the circumstances may prescribe the building inspector and the owner or occupant in charge may agree as to an inspection time by appointment at a time other than during the hours specified above c if any owner occupant or other person in charge of a dwelling or dwelling unit subject to the provisions of this chapter refuses impedes inhibits interferes with restricts or obstructs entry and free access to any part of the structural premises where inspection authorized by this chapter is sought the building inspector may seek from any court of competent jurisdiction an order that such owner occupant or other person in charge cease and desist from such interference prior     part 1997 notice of violation whenever the building inspector determines that there has been a violation or that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provision of this chapter heshe shall give written notice of such violation or alleged violation to the party responsible for maintaining the premises in compliance with this chapter or agent as designated in writing the notice shall a include a description of real estate sufficient for identification  b include a statement of the alleged violation or violations  c include an order for remedial action  d allow reasonable time of up to six months for performance of any action required  e be served upon the responsible party or agent as designated in writing  provided however that such notice shall be deemed to be properly served upon such party if a copy thereof is delivered to him personally or if not found by leaving a copy thereof at hisher usual place of abode in the presence of someone of the family of suitable age and discretion who shall be informed of the contents thereof or by sending a copy thereof by certified mail with return receipt required to hisher last known address or if the certified letter with the copy is returned with a receipt showing it has not been delivered to him by posting a copy thereof in a conspicuous place in or about the dwelling affected by the notice prior     part 1997 minimum housing board created a in order to provide for reasonable interpretation of the provisions of this chapter there is created a minimum housing board consisting of five members who are qualified by experience and training to pass upon matters pertaining to housing b the minimum housing board shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by council the building inspector shall be an ex officio member c any person affected by any notice which has been issued in connection with the enforcement of any provision of this chapter may request and shall be granted a reasonable interpretation d interpretations must be requested within the time limitations specified on the noncompliance notice a oneweek notice must be given to the minimum housing board for all meetings a meeting with the minimum housing board shall not alter or extend the date that compliance must be made by prior     part 1997 emergency orders a if the building inspector shall determine that a dwelling or accessory structure is in such condition that it constitutes a public nuisance and that there is great and immediate danger to the public health safety and welfare and if the owner or occupant if appropriate refuses to comply with orders within the time prescribed the building inspector or other designated officer shall cause such building or part thereof to be closed if unfit for human habitation occupancy or use the inspector shall post a placard on the premises containing the following words this building cannot be used for human habitation occupancy or other use b it is the duty of the building inspector or other designated officer to prohibit the use of the building or part thereof for human habitation occupancy or use until the necessary repairs have been made the procedure followed shall be pursuant to prior     part 1997 unauthorized removal of notice no person shall interfere with obstruct mutilate deface or remove the official notice or placard from any dwelling or from dwelling unit prior     part 1997 minimum standards for equipment and facilities all habitable buildings subject to the provisions of this chapter shall comply with the following requirements for basic equipment and facilities a sinks every dwelling shall contain a kitchen sink which shall be located in the room in which the food is cooked or prepared b bathrooms every dwelling shall contain a bath a flush toilet and a lavatory basin irrespective of the sink required as a kitchen facility except that where there are apartments consisting of not more than three rooms there shall be at least one water closet for each two such apartments the room wherein the flush toilet lavatory basin and bathtub or shower required under this section are installed shall afford privacy to a person within the bathtub or shower may be in a room separate from the room housing the toilet and lavatory basin but shall afford privacy to the person within c water supply every required kitchen sink lavatory basin bathtub or shower shall be properly connected with both hot and cold potable water and every flush water closet shall be properly connected to a supply of water adequate in volume and pressure for flushing purposes d water heating facilities every dwelling unit shall have automatic or manually operated water heating facilities which are properly installed are maintained in safe and good working condition are connected to fixtures as required in of this section and are capable of heating water to a temperature of at least 120 degrees above zero fahrenheit so as to permit an adequate amount of hot water to be drawn at every required sink lavatory basin bathtub or shower even when the required dwelling space heating facilities are not in operation e garbage and refuse receptacles every dwelling unit shall have adequate disposal equipment or receptacles for garbage and rubbish large enough to hold all garbage and rubbish generated by the dwelling unit such receptacles shall comply with the requirements and standards set forth by the department of public works and the city health officer f stairways stairways in dwellings and dwelling units shall be of safe and sound construction equipped with proper handrails mounted not less than two feet and six inches above the nose of the treads and equipped with the treads and risers which are reasonably uniform living spaces located above the ground floor shall have two exits stairways and exits shall comply with the appropriate provisions of the state building codes contained in the wisconsin administrative smoke detectors all dwelling units subject to the provisions of this chapter shall be provided with a properly working approved listed and labeled smoke detector which will be located in the basement and on each floor of the dwelling unit except in the attic or the storage area of the dwelling units 1 the owner or person in charge of the dwelling unit shall be solely responsible for the installation and maintenance of the smoke detectors and for battery replacement as required 2 the tenant shall be responsible for informing the owner in writing of any smoke detector malfunction including the need for a new battery 3 the owner or person in charge of the dwelling unit shall check the battery at the beginning of a new lease and shall replace the battery at least annually as needed 4 the owner or person in charge of the dwelling unit shall furnish to the tenant at the beginning of a new lease written notice of the responsibilities of the tenant and the obligations of the owner regarding smoke detector maintenance h gas ranges when provided or used in any dwelling unit subject to the provisions of this chapter gas ranges ovens and ovenrange combinations of any type shall be installed maintained and used or operated in a safe and nonhazardous manner pursuant to any applicable state or national codes and regulations whenever such an appliance is found or determined to be or certified by the wisconsin power and light co as unsafe or hazardous no person shall use nor shall any person permit others to use the appliance until all appropriate repairs have been made and the appliance is certified as safe for its intended use i doors exterior entryexit doors shall be of solid core construction and capable of affording security by the installation of locking devices bedrooms shall be equipped with doors for privacy prior     part 1997   minimum standards for heating ventilation electrical service and lighting all habitable buildings shall comply with the following requirements for the heating ventilation electrical service and lighting a heating every dwelling shall have heating facilities which are capable of safely and adequately heating all habitable rooms and bathrooms to a temperature of at least 67 degrees above zero fahrenheit with an outside temperature of 15 degrees below zero fahrenheit without forcing the heating facilities beyond safe capacity all facilities shall be operated to maintain at least this minimum temperature during all occupied periods b ventilation every habitable room shall be provided with window andor door areas openable to the outside equal to at least four percent of the floor area except when mechanical ventilation is provided in which case the system shall be designated and installed in accordance with accepted engineering practices 1 every bathroom and toilet compartment shall have at least one window openable to the outside or be equipped with a mechanical exhaust ventilation system to the outside or approved ductless device 2 when flies or other pests are prevalent all windows andor doors openable directly to the outside as required by this section shall be effectively screened 3 all openings to a building or under a mobile home which might provide an entry for rodents shall be effectively protected at all times so as to prevent their entry c electrical service every habitable room shall contain at least two separate walltype electrical convenience outlets or one such convenience outlet and one ceilingtype or walltype electrical fixture  every water closet compartment laundry room furnace room and public hall shall contain at least one ceiling or walltype electric fixture and every bathroom shall contain one wall convenience outlet and one wall or ceiling light fixture every such outlet and fixture shall be properly installed and shall be maintained in a good and safe working condition and shall be connected to the source of the electric power in a safe manner and of a type approved by the state electrical every building accommodating two or more dwelling units using the same corridors and stairways adequate lighting shall be provided in such corridors and stairways when needed such lighting shall be operated by any of the following means 1 light switches in corridors to be conveniently located  2 light switches for stairs shall be at least the equivalent of a threeway light switch system located at the top and bottom of all stairways  3 any automatic type of operation which will maintain adequate lighting at all times either natural or artificial d natural lighting every habitable room shall be provided with window areas equal to at least eight percent of the floor area prior     part 1997 requirements for maintenance all habitable buildings and accessory structures shall comply with the following requirements for maintenance a floors walls etc every floor wall ceiling exterior door foundation and roof shall be weathertight capable of affording privacy kept in good repair and in a clean condition 1 all rainwater shall be so drained from the roof so as not to cause unreasonable dampness in any wall ceiling or floor of a habitable room bathroom or toilet room 2 exterior surfaces shall be painted or suitably surfaced to prevent unreasonable deterioration of the structure 3 all windows shall be maintained in good repair and in a weathertight condition 4 all interior doors shall be maintained in good repair b plumbing systems plumbing shall be maintained in a sanitary and functional condition leaking cracked or broken fixtures shall be considered unsanitary c stairs and porches every inside and outside stair every porch every guardrail and every appurtenance thereto shall be so constructed as to be safe to use and capable of supporting the load that formal use would cause to be placed thereon shall be kept in sound condition good repair and in a clean condition such stairs and porches shall be kept free of refuse stored materials excess furniture and appliances d chimney and smoke pipes every chimney and smoke pipe shall be adequately supported reasonably clean and maintained in a good state of repair and with the proper clearances to combustible building materials e vacant dwelling units to be clean before being let for occupancy no owner shall rent to any person for occupancy or allow any other person to occupy any dwelling unit unless it is safe and clean and complies with all rules and regulations f discontinuance of service no owner occupant or operator shall cause any required service facility equipment or utility to be removed from shut off from or discontinued for any occupied dwelling except for such temporary interruption as may be necessary while actual repairs or alterations are in progress or during a temporary emergency g cleanliness every dwelling unit shall be kept free of any accumulation of rubbish trash debris or other matter if the same tends to create a health andor fire hazard the accumulation or storage of junk wood brick sand gravel cement block or other unsightly debris old automobiles or parts thereof trucks tractors furnaces refrigerators washing machines stoves machinery or parts thereof such as may tend to depreciate the property values in the area or create a nuisance or hazard shall not be allowed in any lot or parcel of land within the corporate limits of the city except as may be allowed by this when such materials are properly housed and out of public view prior     part 1997 conditions of occupancy of dwellings and dwelling units no person shall occupy or let to another any dwelling or dwelling unit for the purpose of living therein which does not comply with the following requirements a floor space every dwelling unit except hotels and roominghouses shall contain at least 150 square feet of habitable floor space for the first occupant thereof and at least an additional 100 square feet of habitable floor space for every additional occupant thereof b habitable room area floor area shall be calculated on the basis of habitable room area however closet area and hall area within the dwelling unit where provided may count for not more than ten percent of the required habitable floor area c access to bathroom facilities every occupant of every dwelling unit shall have unrestricted access to a bath flush toilet sink or lavatory basin located within the dwelling unit such access shall not be than one sleeping room d ceiling height at least onehalf of the floor area of every habitable room shall have a ceiling height of at least seven feet and floor area of that part of any room where the ceiling height is less than five feet shall not be considered as part of the floor area in computing floor area of the room for determining the maximum permissible occupancy thereof e basement space a basement space may be used as living or sleeping rooms of a dwelling unit if floors and walls are impervious to the leakage of underground water surface runoff water excess humidity is controlled and the space used complies with the requirements of habitable rooms in the building code prior     part 1997 responsibility of owner and occupant where in this chapter the obligation for observance is not otherwise clearly designated responsibility of owner operator and occupant is as follows a responsibilities of owner every owner of a dwelling shall be responsible for maintaining in a safe and clean condition all communal shared or public areas of the dwelling and premises b responsibilities of others every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall maintain in a clean condition that part of the dwelling dwelling unit and yard which heshe occupies and controls c disposal of rubbish every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall place all hisher rubbish in proper receptacles d disposal of garbage every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit who does not otherwise provide for the disposal of garbage in a sanitary and inoffensive manner shall prepare all hisher garbage for collection and place it pending collection in a proper receptacle as provided herein 1 the owner shall be responsible for supplying such facilities or receptacles for all dwelling units in dwellings containing more than two dwelling units 2 in all other cases the occupant shall be responsible for such facilities or receptacles e extermination of pests every occupant of a dwelling unit in a dwelling containing more than one dwelling unit shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects rodents pigeons or other pests therein  provided however that when infestation is caused by failure of the owner to maintain a dwelling in a rodent or pigeonproof or substantially insectproof condition or if termites infest the dwelling unit extermination shall be the responsibility of the owner every owner or operator shall be responsible for extermination of any insects rodents pigeons or other pests whenever infestation occurs in more than one dwelling unit in a dwelling or in shared or public parts of a dwelling of two or more units or in any vacant unit f offensive odors no owner or occupant of a dwelling unit may generate offensive odors fumes noise smoke by grilling burning painting etc if the smoke or odor can be a nuisance to neighbors or passersby g responsibility in case of contract a written contract effective between the owner and operator operator and occupant or owner and occupant may alter the responsibilities allocated under this section prior     part 1997 compliance with chapter required for occupancy a from and after one year from the date of adoption of this chapter no dwelling or dwelling units in the city may be occupied if such dwelling or dwelling unit has been inspected by the building inspector and it has been determined that such dwelling or dwelling unit does not conform to the requirements of this chapter b except as to roominghouses which shall be governed by the building inspector shall order compliance with this chapter within a stated period of time not to exceed six months however in cases of hardship heshe may grant at hisher discretion time extensions not exceeding six months each and in any case not exceeding a total of two years from the time of the original order extensions shall be granted only upon evidence of substantial effort to and progress in removing the violation c any dwelling or accessory building declared structurally unsafe shall be restored or razed according to the provisions of wis stats   or in the case of mobile homes or manufactured homes shall be removed the building inspector is designated as an officer to carry out the provisions thereof prior     part 1997 roominghousesstate code compliance no person shall operate a roominghouse or shall occupy or let to another for occupancy any rooming unit in any roominghouse except in compliance with the wisconsin administrative in compliance with the provisions of this chapter  provided that for the purposes of the enforcement of this section the words multiple dwelling or dwelling shall be interpreted to mean roominghouse and dwelling units shall be interpreted to mean rooming units prior     part 1997 sameoperating license a the building inspector is authorized upon application thereof to issue operating licenses and renewals thereof in the manner of applicant owners of roominghouses 1 no such licenses shall be issued unless the roominghouse in connection with which license is sought is found after inspection to meet the requirements of this chapter 2 the building inspector is authorized to issue temporary operating permits for a period not to exceed one year b within 60 days after the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter anyone renting to more than two roomers shall make application to the housing inspector for an operating license c no person shall operate a roominghouse with more than four roomers unless heshe holds a current license or a temporary permit issued by the building inspector in hisher name for the specific roominghouse no permit shall be required where there is in effect a current state board of health hotel motel or tourist home permit prior     part 1997 sameoperating license term and issuance a every operating license shall be issued for a period of one year from the date of issuance unless sooner revoked including any renewals thereof b no operating license shall be issued or renewed unless the applicant owner has first made application therefor on an application form provided by the building inspector accompanied by payment of a license fee in accordance with the citys schedule of fees a copy of which is available for public inspection and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and may be subject to adjustment by the common council from time to time the building inspector shall develop such forms and make them available to the public c no operating license shall be issued or renewed unless the applicant owner agrees in hisher application to such inspection as the building inspector may require to determine whether the roominghouse in connection with which such license is sought is in compliance with the provisions of this chapter prior     part 199 sameoperating license agent for service of notice and process a no operating license shall be issued or renewed for an applicant unless such applicant designates in writing an agent for the receipt of service of the notice of the violation pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and for service of process pursuant to this chapter b such designation shall accompany each application form c the applicant may designate any person or resident in the city as hisher agent for this purpose or may designate the city administrator as hisher agent for this purpose d such applicant shall immediately notify the city administrator of any change in agent prior     part 1997 sameoperating license contents  display  transferability  notice of change of ownership or control a the license shall state the maximum number of occupants permitted on the occupied premises and shall be displayed in a conspicuous place within the communal areas of the roominghouse b no license shall be transferable to another person or roominghouse c every person holding an operating license shall give notice in writing to the building inspector within 48 hours after having transferred or otherwise disposed of the legal control of any licensed roominghouse prior     part 1997 sameinspection  notice of violation a whenever upon inspection of the licensed roominghouse the building inspector finds that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of this chapter heshe shall serve a notice in accordance with this notice shall state that unless the requirements of this chapter are complied with by a specified date the operating license may be revoked b at the end of the time heshe has allowed for correction of any violation cited the building inspector shall reinspect the roominghouse and if heshe determines that such conditions have not been corrected heshe may issue an order revoking the operating license c any person who receives a notice pursuant to this section shall be entitled if heshe requests it to a hearing before the minimum housing board as provided by prior     part 1997 roominghouse minimum requirements a the regulations and standards herein prescribed are minimum standards if any standard or regulation required by the minimum housing code differs from a standard or regulation of some other provision of the minimum housing code or city code or state code the more strict provision shall take precedence b specification of minimum standards 1 at least one flush water closet lavatory basin and bathtub or shower shall be supplied for each ten persons or fractions thereof residing in a roominghouse including members of the operators family when they share the use of the facilities a all rooms containing one water closet with or without a bathtub or shower as required by this section shall be provided with doors with operable locks to ensure privacy to a person within where two or more water closets are provided in the same room for use only by members of same sex each fixture shall be enclosed in accordance with state requirements and doors to such rooms shall not be locked b all rooms containing only one bathtub or shower with or without a water closet shall be provided with doors with locks to ensure privacy to a person within where two or more of such bathing facilities are provided in the same room for only members of the same sex each such facility shall be provided with a shower curtain or door or tub enclosure opening to a common drying and dressing area and doors to such room shall not be locked c urinals where provided for use by members of the same sex shall be in addition to the number of water closets required d one lavatory shall be provided for each water closet e all such facilities shall be so located within the dwelling as to be accessible from a common hall or passageway to all persons sharing such facilities 2 communal cooking and dining facilities in a roominghouse shall be kept by the owner operator or agent designated in writing in a safe sanitary and orderly condition 3 whenever bed linen and towels are furnished by the operator as part of the rental agreement with a room occupant the operator shall change the bed linen and towels prior to the letting of the room to the occupant and at least once a week while the room is occupied and the operator shall be responsible for the maintenance of all such bedding and towels in a clean condition 4 the occupant or occupants of a room in a roominghouse shall be responsible for maintaining the room in a clean condition unless it is stated in the lease that the operator is responsible the operator of every roominghouse shall be responsible for the maintenance of a clean condition in all communal areas and unoccupied rooms of the roominghouse c every sleeping room shall be of sufficient size to afford at least 400 cubic feet of air space for each occupant except that a minimum of 150 cubic feet may be provided for infants in hospital nurseries no greater number of occupants than the number thus established shall be permitted in any such rooms prior     part 1997 violations  penalties a any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall upon conviction be punished by a forfeiture of not less than $5000 for the first offense $10000 for a second offense within 12 months of conviction or $20000 for a third or subsequent offense within 12 months of conviction and not more than $50000 together with the costs of prosecution and in default of payment thereof by imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed 60 days each day of violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense b smoke detectors notwithstanding the foregoing any person convicted of violating shall forfeit not less than $15000 for the first offense and not less than $30000 for the second or subsequent offense within 12 months of conviction and not more than $50000 together with the costs of prosecution and in default of payment thereof by imprisonment in the county jail for a period not to exceed 60 days each day of violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense prior     part 1997 chapter 1516  mobile homes and mobile home parks footnotes  4  state law reference manufactured homes and mobile homes wis stats  10191 et seq  local regulation of manufactured and mobile home communities wis stats   definitions as used in this chapter 1 accessory structure means all structures constructed on a mobile home lot apart from the basic mobile home unit and shall include awnings cabanas storage cabinets or sheds carports windbreaks attached porches and garages 2 common area means any area or space designed for joint use of tenants occupying the mobile home park 3 dependent mobile home means a mobile home which does not have complete bathroom facilities 4 driveway means a minor private way used by vehicles and pedestrians on a mobile home lot or used for common access to a small group of lots or facilities 5 license means a written license issued by the city allowing a person to operate and maintain a mobile home park under the provisions of this chapter and regulations issued hereunder 6 lot area means the total area reserved for exclusive use of the occupants of a mobile home 7 mobile home means a manufactured transportable singlefamily dwelling unit suitable for yearround occupancy containing water supply waste disposal and electrical conveniences and is ready for occupancy except for minor and incidental unpacking and assembly operations at the site  and as defined in wis stats  1e and g and 1g and 1am 8 mobile home lot means a parcel of land located in a mobile home park for the placement of a single mobile home and the exclusive use of its occupants 9 mobile home park means a parcel of land which has been developed for the placement of mobile homes and is owned by an individual a firm trust partnership public or private association or corporation 10 mobile home stand means that part of an individual lot which has been reserved for the placement of one mobile home unit 11 nondependent mobile home means the same as the term mobile home 12 park management means the person who owns or has charge care or control of the mobile home park 13 park street means a private way which affords principal means of access to individual mobile home lots or auxiliary buildings 14 permit means a written permit or certification issued by the city permitting the construction alteration and extension of a mobile home park under the provisions of this chapter and regulations issued hereunder 15 person means any individual firm trust partnership public or private association or corporation 16 tenant storage area means an enclosed space designed to provide auxiliary general storage space for an individual mobile home   part 1994 certain health codes adopted except as otherwise specifically provided for in this chapter the provisions of this to adoption of certain provisions of the wisconsin administrative to mobile home parks inspections by the city health officer and inspection fees are herewith incorporated as part of this chapter and shall be enforced with the same force and effect as though set forth in full herein   part 1994 permits a it is unlawful for any person to construct alter or extend any mobile home park or locate move relocate or remodel or reconstruct any mobile home within the limits of the city unless heshe holds a valid permit issued by the common council or city inspector in the name of such person for the specific construction alteration or extension proposed b all applications for permits shall be filed with the city administrator reviewed by the planning commission and shall contain the following when applicable 1 name and address of the applicant  2 location and legal description of the mobile home park  3 complete engineering plans and specifications of the proposed park showing but not limited to the following a the area and dimensions of the tract of land  b the number location and size of all mobile home lots and the location of common areas  c the location and width of roadways and walkways  d the location of the mobile home stand within the mobile home lot  e plans and specifications of all utilities including sewage collection and disposal stormwater drainage water distribution and supply refuse storage and collection lighting electrical telephone and tv antenna systems  f landscaping plans for the entire park including a planting plan for the buffer strip  g plans and specifications of all buildings to be located within the park  h such other plans and specifications and information as may reasonably be required by the common council  4 a detailed description of repairs reconstruction remodeling or any alterations to be done in the form of a building permit to be issued by the city of omro c no permit shall be issued for the construction of a mobile home park unless the development shall contain a minimum of 20 acres   part 1994 licenses a it is unlawful for any person to operate any mobile home park within the limits of the city unless heshe holds a valid license issued annually by city council in the name of such person for the specific mobile home park all applications for licenses shall be made to the city clerk who shall issue a license upon compliance by the applicant with provisions of this chapter b every person holding a license shall give notice in writing to the city clerk within three days after having sold transferred given away or otherwise disposed of interest in or control of any mobile home park such notice shall include the name and address of the person succeeding to the ownership or control of such mobile home park upon application in writing for transfer of the license and deposit of a fee in accordance with the citys schedule of fees a copy of which is available for public inspection and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and may be subject to adjustment by the common council from time to time the license shall be transferred in the mobile home park is in compliance with all applicable provisions of this chapter c application for original licenses shall be made in writing by the holders of the licenses shall be accompanied by the deposit of a fee in accordance with the citys schedule of fees a copy of which is available for public inspection and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and may be subject to adjustment by the common council from time to time for each 50 lots or fraction thereof and shall contain any change in the information submitted since the original license was issued or the latest renewal granted d in addition to the above license fee the licensee or the owner or the occupant of every mobile home shall pay and be jointly and severally liable for the payment of a monthly parking permit fee to the city such monthly parking permit fee shall be collected by the licensee who is primarily liable for the payment thereof the determination of the amount of such fee the review thereof and the enforcement of the payment and the disposition of such fee shall be in accordance with wis stats  3 and 8 e if upon inspection of any mobile home park or mobile home the mayor or hisher authorized agent find that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of any provision of this chapter written notice in writing in accordance to be served on the person to whom the license was issued unless such conditions or practices are corrected within a reasonable period of time specified in such notice at the end of such period the mayor or hisher authorized agent shall reinspect such mobile home park or mobile home and if such conditions or practices have not been corrected heshe shall suspend the license and give notice in writing of such suspension to the person to whom the license is issued upon receipt of notice of such suspension such person shall cease operation of such mobile home park or vacate such mobile home except as provided in of this section   part 1994 general requirements any person operating a mobile home park shall meet the following requirements intended to promote the health safety and welfare of city residents residing in the mobile home park a environmental requirements 1 density the maximum allowable density in a mobile home park development shall be seven units or lots per acre 2 minimum lot size individual lots within the mobile home park must contain an area of not less than 4000 square feet and a minimum lot width of 40 feet at the building setback line 3 requirement separation between mobile homes mobile homes shall be separated from each other and from other buildings and structures by at least 15 feet an accessory structure such as an awning cabana storage cabinet carport windbreak or porch attached to the mobile home shall for purposes of separation requirements be considered a part of the mobile home detached accessory structures shall be allowed only if included and approved as part of the original or revised mobile home park plan 4 setback and buffer strip a each mobile home shall be located at least five feet from any mobile home lot line b there shall be a minimum distance of 20 feet between the mobile home stand and the back of the curb of the abutting park street c all mobile homes shall be located at least 25 feet from any park property boundary line including public streets d no mobile home shall be located closer than 40 feet from any community building including any washroom toilet or laundry facilities within the park 5 screening a all mobile home parks shall be provided with screening of trees or shrubs along the property boundary line separating the park and such adjacent properties except where the adjoining property is also a mobile home park the planting area shall have a minimum width of 15 feet within such a planting area there shall be established within six months after issuance of the license for the occupation of such mobile home park the following plantings b a permanent planting of trees and shrubs so arranged and in sufficient numbers so as to form a solid wall of plant material such planting shall be grown or maintained at a height of not less than 15 feet except where line of sight vision is necessary for pedestrians or vehicular traffic safety 6 allowable uses singlefamily mobile homes as defined by this chapter shall be allowed and any approved accessory structures included in the original plans and specifications or revisions thereof dependent mobile homes shall specifically be prohibited from placement within mobile home parks 7 recreation areas each mobile home park shall devote at least ten percent of its total area to common space provided for the recreational use and enjoyment of the occupants of the park such open space should where conditions permit be centrally located so as to be free from traffic hazards parks playgrounds and open space shall be allowed as well as the following commercial uses when they are for the exclusive use of park residents a mobile home park office  b laundromat  c clubhouse and facilities for private social or recreation clubs  d storage building 8 signs signs pertaining to the lease hire or sale of individual mobile homes not more than two square feet in area shall be allowed as well as one mobile home park identification sign not more than 50 square feet in area to be located in proximity to the park entrance b access requirements 1 general requirements all mobile home parks shall be provided with safe and convenient vehicular access from abutting public streets or roads to each mobile home lot such access shall be provided by streets driveways or other means 2 park entrance entrances to mobile home parks shall be designed to minimize congestion and hazards and allow free movement of traffic on adjacent streets 3 internal streets  surfaced roadways shall be of adequate width to accommodate anticipated traffic and in any case shall meet the following minimum requirements a roadway width all streets 24 feet  b dead end streets culdesacs shall be limited in length to 1000 feet and shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having an outside roadway diameter of at least 60 feet 4 street construction and design standards a design standards all interior streets shall be designed and located in accordance with the requirements of this to land subdivision regulations b pavements all park streets shall be provided with a minimum of nine inches crushed stone base covered with a threeinch asphalt surface concrete curb and gutter shall be required on all streets c parking requirements 1 occupant parking a minimum of two parking spaces shall be provided for occupant parking purposes such spaces shall be located within 250 feet of the mobile home lot to be served 2 visitor parking a minimum of one space for every four mobile home lot shall be provided for visitor parking purposes 3 parking space each parking space shall contain a minimum of 200 square feet the space shall be paved with a smooth hard and dense surface which shall be durable and welldrained under normal use and weather conditions 4 parking restrictions parking of boats trailers campers snowmobiles or other similar vehicles shall be restricted to an area provided by the park management specifically for such purpose 5 monthly parking fee  limitations on parking a there is imposed on each owner of a nonexempt occupied mobile home in the city a monthly parking fee as determined in accordance with wis stats  3 which is adopted by reference and made part of this chapter as if fully set forth herein it shall be the full and complete responsibility of the licensee to collect the proper amount from each mobile home owner licensees shall pay to the city administrator such parking permit fees on or before the tenth day of the month following the month for which such fees are due in accordance with the terms of this section and such regulations as the city administrator may reasonably promulgate i licensees of mobile home parks and owners of land on which are parked any occupied nonexempt mobile homes shall furnish information to the city administrator and assessor on such homes added to their park or land within five days after arrival of such home on forms furnished by the city administrator ii occupants or owners of nonexempt mobile homes parked outside of a mobile home park shall remit such fees directly to the city administrator as provided in a of this section it shall be the full and complete responsibility of the licensee of a mobile home park to collect such fees from each occupied nonexempt mobile home therein and to remit such fees to the city administrator as provided in a of this section b owners of nonexempt occupied mobile homes upon receipt of notice from the city administrator of their liability for the monthly parking permit fee shall remit payment to the city administrator a cash deposit of $2500 to guarantee payment of such fees when due to the city it shall be the full and complete responsibility of the licensees of a mobile home park to collect such cash deposits from each occupied nonexempt mobile home therein and to remit such deposits to the city administrator upon receipt of a notice from the owner or licensee that the nonexempt occupied mobile home has been or is about to be removed from the city the city administrator shall apply the cash deposit to reduce any monthly parking permit fees for which the owner is liable and refund the balance if any to the owner c it is unlawful for any person to park a mobile home outside a mobile home park in the city d walkways all parks shall be provided with safe convenient allseason pedestrian access of adequate width for intended use durable and convenient to maintain between individual mobile homes the park streets and all community facilities provided for park residents 1 common walk system a common walk system shall be provided and maintained between locations where pedestrian traffic is concentrated such common walks shall have a minimum width of 312 feet 2 individual walks all mobile home stands shall be connected to common walks to paved streets or to paved driveways or parking spaces connected to a paved street or roadway such individual walks shall have a minimum width of two feet e mobile home stand 1 for the purpose of this chapter a mobile home stand shall be defined as an area of 15 feet by 70 feet the area of the mobile home stand shall be improved to provide adequate support for the placement and tie down of the mobile home thereby securing the super structure against uplift sliding rotation and overturning 2 anchors and tie downs shall be placed at least at each corner of the mobile home stand and each shall be able to sustain a minimum tensile strength of 2800 pounds f site suitability and stormwater drainage condition of soil groundwater level drainage and topography shall not create hazards to the property or the health or safety of the occupants 1 soil and groundcover requirements exposed ground surfaces in all parts of the mobile home park that are not paved covered with stone screenings or other solid material shall be protected with a vegetative growth that is capable of preventing soil erosion and of eliminating objectionable dust 2 site drainage requirements the ground surface in all parts of every mobile home park shall be graded and equipped to drain all surface water in a safe efficient manner g water supply and sewerage disposal system the mobile home park shall make connection to the city water supply and sewerage disposal systems at the boundary of the site the mobile home park water distribution system shall provide sixinch water mains and these mains shall be looped wherever possible the mobile home park sewer system shall be constructed and maintained according to standards in wis admin nr 110 h refuse storage and collection system 1 all refuse shall be stored in flytight watertight rodentproof containers which shall be located not more than 250 feet from any mobile home lot containers shall be provided in sufficient number and capacity to properly store all refuse 2 refuse collection stands shall be provided for all refuse containers such container stands shall be so designed as to prevent containers from being tipped to minimize spillage and container deterioration and to facilitate cleansing around them 3 all refuse containing garbage shall be collected at regular intervals where suitable collection service is not available from public or private agencies the mobile home park operator shall provide this service all refuse shall be collected and transported in covered vehicles or covered containers 4 in no instance may disposal of the waste be carried out on the mobile home park site i public utility system all utility service systems shall be installed and maintained in accordance with applicable codes and regulations governing such systems 1 public utility service outlets shall be provided at each mobile home stand for electric telephone and gas 2 all utility service lines shall be located underground within the mobile home park j street and public walkway illumination requirements all parks shall be furnished with lighting units so spaced and equipped with luminaries placed at such mounting heights as will provide the following average maintained levels of illumination for the safe movement of pedestrians and vehicles at night 1 fires shall be made only in barbecue pits fireplaces stoves or other equipment intended for such purposes incinerators shall be prohibited 2 portable fire extinguisher rated for class a b and c fires shall be kept in service buildings and shall be maintained in good operating condition their capacity shall not be less than 212 pounds 3 fire hydrants shall be located within 300 feet of any mobile home service building or other structure in the park prior     part 1994  a  2 1996 responsibility of the park management a the person to whom a license for a mobile home park is issued shall operate the park in compliance with this chapter and shall provide adequate supervision to maintain the park its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition b the park management shall notify park occupants of all applicable provisions of this chapter and inform them of their duties and responsibilities under this chapter c the park management shall supervise the placement of each mobile home on its mobile home stand which includes securing its stability and installing all utility connections d the park management shall maintain a register containing the names of all park occupants identified by lot number or street address a copy of such register listing all of such information and all monthly charges as of the first day of each month shall be mailed to the city clerk by the park management on or before the tenth day of each month e the park management shall collect the monthly parking permit fee f the undercarriage supports and stabilizing devices of the mobile home shall be skirted and secured by a mobile home stand both being done to be attractive to the appearance of the community   part 1994 responsibilities of park occupants a park occupants shall comply with all applicable requirements of this chapter and shall provide adequate supervision to maintain the park its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition b park occupants shall be responsible for proper placement of their mobile homes on its mobile home stand and proper installation of all utility connections in accordance with the instructions of the park management c pets if permitted in the park shall be prohibited to run at large or to commit any nuisance within the limits of any mobile home lot d porches awnings and other additions shall be installed only if permitted and approved by the park management and after obtaining a permit from the city inspectors office if necessary when installed all porches awnings and additions shall be maintained in safe and good repair the space immediately below a mobile home shall be for storage if permitted by the park management if permitted the following conditions shall be satisfied 1 the storage area shall be provided with a base of impervious material  2 stored items shall be located so as not to interfere with the underneath inspection of the mobile home  3 the storage area shall be enclosed by skirting e park occupants shall store and dispose of all their rubbish and garbage in a clean sanitary and safe manner all garbage containers shall be rodentproof insectproof and watertight   part 1994 location of mobile homes a mobile homes intended for purposes of human habitation are prohibited within the corporate limits of the city except as licensed for mobile home park use in compliance with this chapter or except as provided in subsections b and c of this section b the city health department when satisfied that proper sanitation and health standards will be met may issue permits for the parking of not more than one trailer on private premises where such parking is in connection with a bona fide visit of the owner or occupant of the trailer with individuals living within the city and such stay will not exceed 14 days the fee for a temporary parking permit shall be in accordance with the citys schedule of fees a copy of which is available for public inspection and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and may be subject to adjustment by the common council from time to time c the city clerk is authorized to issue temporary permits for the parking of trailers to be used as field offices during the construction of a building project on the construction site only  provided that such is not used for overnight lodging nor connected to the city water or sewer system application for such permit shall be made on the forms prepared and furnished by the clerk and shall be accompanied by a fee in accordance with the citys schedule of fees a copy of which is available for public inspection and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and may be subject to adjustment by the common council from time to time the permit shall not exceed 12 months from the issuance thereof but may be renewed on a monthtomonth basis until the completion of the building project or the removal of the trailer   part 1994 variances any person may apply for a variance from the provisions of this chapter to the city board of zoning appeals   part 1994 inspection of mobile home parks  generally a the mayor or hisher authorized agent is authorized and directed to make such inspections as are necessary to determine satisfactory compliance with this chapter b the mayor or hisher authorized agent shall have the power to enter at reasonable times upon any private or public property for the purpose of inspecting and investigating conditions relating to the enforcement of this chapter c the mayor or hisher authorized agent shall have the power to inspect the register containing a record of all residents of the mobile home park d it shall be the duty of the park management to give the mayor or hisher authorized agent free access to all lots at reasonable times for the purpose of inspection   part 1994 inspection of premises  building inspector a 1 the building inspector is authorized and directed to make inspection when heshe has valid reason to believe that a violation of this chapter has occurred 2 the building inspector is authorized to enter and inspect all mobile home parks and mobile homes units subject to the provisions of this chapter between  am and  pm except sundays and holidays for the purpose of determining whether there is compliance with the provisions of this chapter heshe shall give the occupant thereof or if there is none then the owner thereof reasonable notice of hisher intent to inspect the premises and may then make hisher inspection only if heshe is given permission to do so in the absence of such permission heshe shall obtain a search warrant before entering the premises however if delay in inspection would pose a serious and imminent threat to human life health or property heshe may enter the premises without such permission or notice and with or without a search warrant as the circumstances may prescribe the housing inspector and the owner or occupant in charge may agree to an inspection by appointment at a time other than during the hours specified above 3 if any owner occupant or other person in charge of a mobile home park or mobile home subject to the provisions of this chapter refuses impedes inhibits interferes with restricts or obstructs entry and free access to any part of the structural premises where inspection authorized by this chapter is sought the housing inspector may seek from any court of competent jurisdiction an order that such owner occupant or other person in charge cease and desist with such interference b whenever the building inspector determines that there has been a violation or that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there has been a violation of any provisions of this chapter heshe shall give written notice of such violation alleged to the party responsible for maintaining the premises in compliance with this chapter or agent as designated in writing and 1 include a description of the real estate or site sufficient for identification  2 include a statement or statements concerning the alleged violations  3 include an order for remedial action  4 allow a reasonable time up to six months for performance as required   part 1994 appeals from orders of building inspector any person feeling aggrieved by any order or ruling of the building inspector may appeal from such order or ruling to the board of zoning appeals within five calendar days after written notice of such order or ruling being delivered to the aggrieved person such appeal shall be in writing and shall be filed with the city clerk a majority of the voting members of the zoning board of appeals shall be sufficient to sustain the order of the building inspector   part 1994 emergency orders a if the building inspector shall determine that a mobile home park or mobile home is in such a condition as to constitute a public nuisance and that there is a great danger to the public health safety and welfare and if the owner or occupant if appropriate refuses to comply with the orders within the time prescribed the building inspector shall cause the use of such mobile home park or mobile home to be posted unfit for human habitation occupancy or use by posting a placard containing the following words these premises or mobile home cannot be used for human habitation occupancy or use b it shall further be the duty of the building inspector to notify the owner or occupants whichever applies that such premises or mobile home are unfit for human habitation occupancy or use and shall not be occupied until approval by the building inspector   part 1994 violations  penalties any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall upon conviction be punished by a forfeiture of not less than $25000 for each offense each day of violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense   part 1994 chapter 1520  historic preservation purpose and intent it is declared a matter of public policy that the protection enhancement perpetuation and use of designated improvements or sites of special character or special architectural archeological or historic interest or value is in the public interest and that the preservation of such improvements and sites is in the interest of the health prosperity safety and welfare of the citizens of the city the following are expressly declared to be the purposes of this chapter a effect and accomplish the protection enhancement and preservation of such improvements sites and districts that represent or reflect elements of the citys cultural social economic political and architectural history while simultaneously preserving the rights of individuals to decide how to best utilize their private property  b safeguard the citys historic prehistoric and cultural heritage as embodied and reflected in such historic structures sites and districts subject to the recognized interest individuals possess in the use of their private property  c stabilize and improve property values and enhance the visual and aesthetic character of the city whenever this can be accomplished after considering the interests of the private property owner  d protect and enhance the citys attractions to residents tourists and visitors and to serve as a support and stimulus to business and industry   part 1996 definitions the following terms shall have the following meanings when used in this chapter 1 certificate of appropriateness means the certificate issued by the commission approving alteration rehabilitation reconstruction or demolition of a designated historic structure historic site or any improvement in a properly designated historic district 2 commission means the planning commission which shall function as the historic preservation commission 3 historic district means a geographic area nominated by all of the legal owners of record for real property located within the area so nominated which has been designated by the city council on recommendation of the commission as per the requirements of this chapter 4 historic site means any parcel of land having historic significance due to the lands substantial value in tracing the history or prehistory of man or upon which a historic event has occurred after the parcel has been so designated as a historic site as per the requirements of this chapter 5 historic structure means any improvement nominated by the legal owners of record that has a special character or special historic interest or value as part of the development heritage or cultural heritage of the city and that has been designated as a historic structure pursuant to the provisions of this chapter 6 improvement means any building structure place work of art or other object constituting a physical betterment of real property or any part of such betterment including streets alleys sidewalks curbs lighting fixtures signs and the like 7 legal owner of record means the legal owner of a parcel structure site or improvement as reflected on the records of the city administrator on the date of nomination for any classification as provided under this chapter   part 1996 designation criteria and operating guidelines a designation criteria for purposes of this chapter a historic structure historic site or historic district designation may be placed on any site natural or improved including any building improvement or structure located thereon or any area of particular historic architectural archeological or cultural significance to the city such as historic structures sites or districts subject to the requirement of designation as provided hereunder that 1 exemplifies or reflects the broad cultural political economic or social history of the nation state or community  2 identifies with historic personages or with important events in national state or local history  3 embodies distinguishing characteristics of an architectural type or specimen inherently valuable for a study of a period style method of construction or of indigenous materials or craftsmanship  4 represents notable work of a master builder designer or architect who influenced hisher age  or 5 yields or may be likely to yield information important to prehistory or history b operating guidelines the commission may adopt specific operating guidelines for historic structure historic site and historic district designation provided such are in conformance with the provisions of this chapter c nomination no structure site or district may be classified as historic under the terms of this chapter unless the property owner the legal owner of record of the site andor structure to be so classified on the date that the subject structure site or district is nominated hereunder by way of filing a nomination petition with the commission indicating that the site structure or district in question meets the historical criteria established under subsection a of this section petitions the commission for such classification only upon nomination by a propertys legal owner of record may the commission take such action as provided in   part 1996 historic preservation commission  powers and duties a power to designate upon nomination of a property improvement or site as historic under the commission shall have the power subject to to designate historic structures and historic sites and to recommend designation of nominated historic districts such designations shall be made based on criteria set forth in historic districts shall be approved by the city council once designated such historic structures sites and districts shall be subject to all the provisions of this chapter a nomination by a property owner allows but does not require the commission to designate the nominated structure or site as historical as defined hereunder upon nomination the commission is authorized to proceed under the terms and conditions as referenced hereunder once designated a structure site or district shall be subject to the requirements of this chapter notwithstanding a subsequent saleconveyance of the property to a subsequent legal owner of record b regulation of construction reconstruction alteration and demolition 1 no owner or person in charge of a designated historic structure historic site or structure within a historic district shall reconstruct alter or demolish all or any part of the exterior of such property or construct any improvement upon such designated property or properties or cause or permit any such work to be performed upon such designated property or demolish such property unless a certificate of appropriateness has been granted by the commission the building inspector shall not issue a permit for any such work on a designated building unless such certificate has been granted by the commission 2 upon filing of any application for a certificate of appropriateness with the commission the commission shall approve the application unless a in the case of a designated historic structure or historic site the proposed work would detrimentally change destroy or adversely affect any exterior feature of the improvement or site upon which the work is to be done  b in the case of the construction of a new improvement upon a historic site or within a historic district the exterior of such improvement would adversely affect or not harmonize with the external appearance of other neighboring improvements on such site or within the district  c in the case of any property located in a historic district the proposed construction reconstruction exterior alteration or demolition does not conform to the purpose and intent of this chapter and to the objectives and design criteria of the historic preservation plan for the district  d the building or structure is of such architectural or historical significance that its demolition would be detrimental to the public interest and contrary to the general welfare of the people of the city  e in the case of a request for the demolition of a deteriorated building or structure any economic hardship or difficulty claimed by the owner is selfcreated or is the result of any failure to maintain the property in good repair 3 if the commission determines that the application for a certificate of appropriateness and the proposed changes are consistent with the character and features of the property or district it shall issue the certificate of appropriateness the commission shall make its decision on whether to issue a certificate of appropriateness within 30 days of the filing of the application 4 the issuance of a certificate of appropriateness shall not relieve the applicant from obtaining other permits and approvals required by the city a building permit or other municipal permit shall be null and void if obtained without the acquisition of a certificate of appropriateness when required under the terms of this chapter 5 ordinary maintenance and repairs may be undertaken without a certificate of appropriateness provided that the work involves repairs to existing features of a historic structure or site or the replacement of elements of a structure with pieces identical in appearance and provided that the work does not change the exterior appearance of the structure or site and does not require the issuance of a building permit c appeals should the commission fail to issue a certificate of appropriateness due to the failure of the proposal to conform to the applicable guidelines the applicant may appeal such decision to the city council within 30 days in addition if the commission fails to issue a certificate of appropriateness the commission shall with the cooperation of the applicant work with the applicant in an attempt to obtain a certificate of appropriateness d recognition of historic structures sites and districts at such time as a historic structure site or district has been properly designated the commission in cooperation with the property owner may cause to be prepared and erected on such property at city expense a suitable plaque declaring that such property is a historic structure site or within a properly designated historic district   part 1996 procedures a designation of historic structures and historic sites 1 the commission may after nomination by the affected property owners and after notice and public hearing designate historic structures andor historic sites or rescind such designation after application of the criteria in at least ten days prior to such hearing the commission shall notify the legal owners of record as listed in the office of the city administrator of property in whole or in part situated within 200 feet of the boundaries of the nominated property 2 the commission shall then conduct such public hearing and in addition to the notified persons may hear expert witnesses and shall have the power to subpoena such witnesses and records as it deems necessary the commission may conduct an independent investigation into the proposed designation or rescission within ten days after the close of the public hearing the commission may designate the property as either a historic structure or a historic site or rescind the designation after the designation or rescission has been made notification shall be sent to the property owner or owners notification shall also be given to the city administrator building inspector and planning commission the commission shall cause the designation or rescission to be recorded at city expense in the county register of deeds office b creation of historic district 1 for preservation purposes the commission may upon nomination by all the affected legal owners of record of property to be included within a proposed district recommend a geographically defined area within the city to be designated as a historic district to the city council and may prepare a historic preservation plan for such area a historic district may be designated for any geographic area of particular historic architectural or cultural significance to the city upon appropriate nomination by all the affected property owners and after application of the criteria in each historic preservation plan prepared for or by the commission shall include a cultural and architectural analysis supporting the historic significance of the area the specific guidelines for development and a statement of preservation objectives no property owner at the time of the nomination may have hisher property included in the district unless the property owner consents to the nomination in writing upon designation the propertydistrict boundaries so designated as defined by the property owners joining in the nomination for the formation of the historic district shall be subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter which shall bind all subsequent purchases and later legal owners of record within the affected geographic area 2 review and adoption procedure for historic districts a the commission shall hold a public hearing when considering the plan for a nominated historic district notice of the time place and purpose of the public hearing shall be sent by the city clerk to the alderperson of the city wards in which the historic district is located and the legal owners of record as listed in the office of the city administrator of the property within the proposed historic district or are situated in whole or in part within 200 feet of the boundaries of the proposed historic district the notice shall be sent at least ten days prior to the date of the public hearing following the public hearing the commission shall vote to recommend reject or withhold action on the plan only legal owners of record owning property within the proposed historic
